title: Water-Lily Vessel

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of ceramic and pigment.

artist_display:
Ah Maxam
Maya, active mid-/late 8th century
Vicinity of Naranjo, Petén region, Guatemala
description: The simple, elegant design of this vessel reflects the refined abilities of the artist, who painted images of water lilies and a hieroglyphic text with a perfectly controlled brush. The inscription below was the first to be deciphered on a Classic Maya vessel. It states the name of the artist, Ah Maxam (aj maxam), and declares that he is a member of the royal lineage of the kingdom of Naranjo. His mother and father are also named on this vessel, as well as on other dynastic monuments from the region. For the Maya, water lilies were symbolic of the watery surface of the Underworld and the earth’s regenerative powers.
publication_history: Michael Coe, The Maya Scribe and His World, exh. cat. (Grolier Club, 1973), 102–103, no. 47. Everette McNear, High Culture in the Americas before 1500, exh. cat. (Arts Club Chicago, 1982), 9, 15. Dorie Reents-Budet, “The Discovery of a Ceramic Artist and Royal Patron Among the Classic Maya.” MexIcon 9, 6 (1987) 123–26, fig. 2. Dorie Reents-Budet, “Elite Maya Pottery and Artisans as Social Indicators,” Archeological Papers of the American Anthropological Association, 8, 1 (1988): 71–89. David Stuart, “Hieroglyphs on Maya Vessels,” Maya Vase Book, vol. 1, Justin Kerr, ed. (New York, Kerr Associates, 1989), 149–159, fig. 9 . Richard F. Townsend, ed., The Ancient Americas: Art from Sacred Landscapes, exh. cat. (Art Institute of Chicago/Prestel Verlag, 1992), cat. 126. Dorie Reents-Budet, Painting the Maya Universe: Royal Ceramics of the Classic Period, exh. cat. (Duke University Museum of Art, 1994), 319, cat. 10. Adam Hering, “A Royal Artist at Naranjo: Notes on a Late Classic Maya Cylinder Vessel,” Yale University Art Gallery Bulletin (1995-96), 35-48, fig. 4. Dorie Reents-Budet, “Neutron Activation and Maya Pottery,” presented at Texas Conference of Art Historians (Apr. 27, 1985), unpublished report, copy in curatorial object file, Arts of the Americas. Mary Miller and Simon Martin, Courtly Art of the Ancient Maya, exh. cat. (Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco and Thames & Hudson, 2003), 153. Richard Townsend with Elizabeth Pope, Indian Art of the Americas at the Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago and Yale University Press, 2016), 200, cat. 157. Christophe Helmke, Yuriy Polyukhovych, Dorie J. Reents-Budet, and Ronald Bishop, “A Bowl Fit for a King: Ceramic Vessels of the Naranjo Court Bearing the Kokom Emblem Glyph,” The PARI Journal (2017) 18(1), 9-24, 13, fig. 2b [K635/MS1375].
exhibition_history: Rockford College Art Gallery, IL, Nov.–Dec. 1971, no cat. Grolier Club, N.Y., The Maya Scribe and His World, Apr. 20–June 5, 1971, cat. 47. Arts Club of Chicago, High Culture in the Americas before 1500, Nov. 15–Dec. 31, 1982, cat. 15. Art Institute of Chicago, The Ancient Americas: Art from Sacred Landscapes, Oct. 10, 1992–Jan. 3, 1993, cat. 126; Houston, Museum of Fine Arts, Feb. 4–Apr. 18, 1993; Los Angeles County Museum of Art, June 6–Aug. 15, 1993. Durham, NC, Duke University Museum of Art, Painting of the Maya Universe, Jan. 15–Mar. 27, 1994, cat. plate 10; Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, Apr. 15–June 26, 1994; Denver Art Museum, July 15–Sept. 15, 1994; Los Angeles County Museum, Oct. 8, 1994–Jan. 8, 1995; New Haven, CT, Yale University Art Gallery, Feb. 10–Apr. 23, 1995. provenance_text: Marianne and Robert Huber, Dixon, IL, by 1969 [according to correspondence from M. Huber, Feb. 14, 1986, and P. Dedrick, Rockford College, Oct. 7 and Oct. 28, 1986, copy in curatorial object file]; sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1986.
